data.title: What Margaret and David say about 500 Oz Movies
data.meta_description: Margaret Pomeranz and David Stratton are Australia’s best known and much-loved film critics, having appeared on two long-running weekly movie TV review shows for almost 30 years: SBS’s The Movie Show from 1986 to 2004 and ABC’s At The Movies between 2004 and 2014. Like Bill Collins and John Hinde did before them, they reviewed…
data.text:
Margaret Pomeranz and David Stratton are Australia’s best known and much-loved film critics, having appeared on two long-running weekly movie TV review shows for almost 30 years: SBS’s The Movie Show from 1986 to 2004 and ABC’s At The Movies between 2004 and 2014. Like Bill Collins and John Hinde did before them, they reviewed both international and Australian movies, and their informed opinions and knowledge of classical cinema helped open Australians’ eyes to both our own films and movies from all around the world.

Margaret and David were like our cinematic godparents, taking us by the hands, and guiding us through the world of film, explaining, analysing, comparing and teaching us a vocabulary to discuss what we were seeing. And when they finally retired from the ABC in 2014, thousands (perhaps millions) of Australian cinephiles were left bereft, to wander like orphans in the new cinematic world, getting lost in the flood of new trends, with only the increasingly distant memories from the many years under their care to guide us.

So what Oz films did Margaret and David like?

Remembering that Margaret and David did not generally review films made before 1986, and that reviews of some major films made in or after 1986 (including Crocodile Dundee, Strictly Ballroom and The Year My Voice Broke) were not found (see Notes at end), their top five Oz films, the only ones to which I know they both gave five stars were:

Evil Angels, Lantana, The Piano, Return Home and Samson & Delilah

Margaret also gave 5 stars to Flirting and David also gave five stars to eight other films:

Bad Boy Bubby, Happy Feet, Shine, Grievous Bodily Harm, Holy Smoke, Idiot Box, The Quiet Room, and The Year My Voice Broke*

Both David and Margaret gave 4½ stars to another 21 films:

Animal Kingdom, Babe, Beautiful Kate, The Boys, Burning Man, Children Of The Revolution, Chopper, Death in Brunswick, The Dish, The Finished People, Head On. The Heartbreak Kid, The Interview, Japanese Story, Look Both Ways, Praise, Proof, Sirens, Somersault and The Tracker.

Margaret was less generous with her five-star ratings, but was slightly more generous overall, giving Oz films 3.6 stars on average, ahead of David’s 3.4 stars.

David was also harder on movies he didn’t like, giving 0, ½ or 1 star to seven movies (including his controversial refusal to rate the highly regarded Romper Stomper due to the film’s depictions of racist violence) and only 1½ stars to another seven films, including The Castle, which became one of Australia’s most popular films. Margaret only gave less than two stars to four films.

The films on which they most disagreed, apart from Romper Stomper, were:

The Castle David: 1.5 stars – Margaret: 4 stars

Last Train To Freo David: 1.5 stars – Margaret: 4 stars

Human Touch David: 4.5 stars – Margaret: 2 stars

Kenny David: 2.5 stars – Margaret: 4.5 stars

Overall though, Margaret and David tended to give similar ratings, differing by only half a star in 70% of their reviews.

Their ratings and reviews of Oz films follow.

David and Margaret’s Reviews of Oz Movies 1986-2014

The list below has links to Margaret and David’s video reviews of over 500 Oz movies released mainly while Margaret and David were appearing on SBS’s The Movie Show and ABC’s At The Movies between 1986-2014. For more information, see the Notes below the list.

Update 1: As of sometime in 2017, the ABC website removed their At The Movies collection, and the links I had for movies released between 2004 and 2014, no longer functioned. I have fixed this so that ABC links now lead to the archived version of the reviews on the Wayback Machine Internet Archive (which is just as good really as they contain the full text plus videos in many cases). You can also go to the At the Movies Index on the Wayback Machine and find reviews of other films if you wish.

Update 2: As of late 2017 or early 2018, SBS moved all of their Movie Show reviews to their On-Demand streaming service. This means that some links may no longer work (although most still seem to).

Notes on the list

I compiled this list in 2016 from the ABC At the Movies (now removed but a copy is at At the Movies Index on the Wayback Machine), and SBS Movie Reviews websites, but had to search quite hard to find some of the entries, and didn’t manage to find some. Note also that the list above is not restricted to the Ozflick’s definition of an Australian film, including as it does Australian productions of non-Australian stories.

The ABC website (now in its archived version) is slightly easier to navigate: they have their reviews organised alphabetically and they had a good search engine. However you could only search for titles and the Oz films weren’t gathered or gatherable en masse, so you either searched for a film you knew, or browsed the alphabetical list for titles you recognised.

The SBS website contains a greater number of reviews than the ABC, but is slightly harder to find your way around, as they don’t have a search engine solely for movies. I started by checking Movie by Reviewer for David and Margaret, which finds a lot of their reviews. However I found that there were many others on the SBS website which did not appear under David’s or Margaret’s lists. Other problems with the SBS reviews are: some review videos cut out before M&D announce their scores; some videos are missing from the movie page; and some pages only have interviews without M&D’s reviews. Reviews of some quite high profile films during those years, such as Strictly Ballroom, Bliss, Crocodile Dundee and The Year My Voice Broke, are missing. (Although I could not find the review, it is clear that David gave The Year My Voice Broke 5 stars – David said he did in the review for Flirting.)

Margaret and David have continued to produce reviews separately since 2014, Margaret for Foxtel and David for The Australian (see also here), but I have not included those reviews here.

If you are able to help in finding any more of Margaret and David’s reviews together or their ratings for other Oz films, could you please contact me or leave a comment below?

PS. By August 2017, through more careful searching, and using the great Australian film lists at Australasian Cinema, I managed to increase the number of reviews on the list by over 100, to 530, though I was still unable to find the reviews or scores for Strictly Ballroom and The Year My Voice Broke.

When The Movie Show started in 1986, Margaret and David did not give ratings for their films. In 1987 they started to rate films out of four stars, and in 1988 they started to give ratings out of five stars, a practice they continued until the end.
